title: Narendra Singh & Ors. vs The State Of M.P on 16 August, 2012
doc:
Narendra Singh & Ors. vs The State Of M.P on 16 August, 2012

  HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE MADHYA PRADESH,
                  JABAPLUR

      Single Bench: Hon'ble Shri Justice N.K.Gupta,J

              CRIMINAL APPEAL No.2061 OF 1996

                         Narendra Singh & others.
                                           Vs.
                          State of Madhya Pradesh.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Shri Neeraj Ashar, Advocate for the appellants.

Shri G.S.Thakur, Panel Lawyer for the respondent/State.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                                JUDGMENT

(Delivered on the 16th day of August, 2012) This criminal appeal is preferred by the appellants being aggrieved by the judgment and order of sentence dated 29/10/1996 passed by the Additional Sessions Judge, Panna in ST No.31/1993, whereby the appellants were convicted for commission of offence punishable under Section 25(1) of the Arms Act and sentenced for three years' rigorous imprisonment.

2. The prosecution's case, in short, is that in the night of 19th & 20th October 1992 at about 2:00 AM Shri S. Panveliwala (PW-8) SHO Police Station Kotwali, Panna got an information that some culprits were gathered at the house of appellant Narendra Singh and making a plan to commit dacoity. Shri S. Panveliwala collected the police force including the Head Constable Ramkishore (PW-1), 2 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 Head Constable Gaya Prasad (PW-2), Sub Inspector M.M.Bati (PW-4) and went to the spot. They heard the talks took place between the appellants that they were planning to commit a dacoity in 2-4 houses of NMDC colony. The police force entered into the room and captured all the appellants. The appellants kept some firearms with them and those firearms were seized according to the seizure memo Ex.P-4 to P-11. The appellants were taken to the Police Station after their arrest. A case was registered against them for commission of offence punishable under Sections 399, 402 of IPC as well as Section 25 of the Arms Act. The seized weapons were sent to the Forensic Science Laboratory for their examination vide memo Ex.P-15 and report Ex.P-16 was received by which it was opined that out of all the weapons, one weapon was an air gun, whereas weapon seized from the appellant Motilal was not working, as no liver-sear was found in that double barrel gun. After getting a sanction to prosecute the appellants under Section 39 of the Arms Act from the District Magistrate, Panna, a charge sheet was filed before the Chief Judicial Magistrate, Panna, who committed the case to the Sessions Judge, Panna and ultimately it was transferred to the Additional Sessions Judge, Panna.

3. The appellants-accused abjured their guilt. They took a specific plea that they were relatives and servants of Rajmata Dharmakumari and some of the firearms were kept 3 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 in the chest of her majesty. The appellants were sleeping in the house of Rajmata Dharmakumari and they were falsely implicated in the matter due to her quarrel with one Khunna Raja. The police had acted according to the wishes of Khunnu Raja. A false case was prepared. In defence Lokendra Singh (DW-1) and Narendra Singh (DW-4) were examined to show that they were arrested unnecessarily by the police when they were sleeping in the house and various guns were seized by the police from the safe of Rajmata Dharmakumari by breaking its latch. The Arms Clerk S.L. Verma (DW-3) was examined to show that the seized weapons were licensed in the name of Smt. Dharmakumari whereas Suraj Prasad Awasthi (DW-2) was examined to show that one gun was given for its repairing to Suraj Prasad Awasthi (DW-2) which was obtained by the police directly with the help of appellant Narendra Singh from the shop of Suraj Prasad Awasthi.

4. After considering the evidence adduced by the parties, the learned Additional Sessions Judge Panna acquitted all the appellants for commission of offence punishable under Sections 399 and 402 of IPC, but convicted them for commission of offence punishable under Section 25(1)(a) of the Arms Act and sentenced as mentioned above.

5. I have heard the learned counsel for the parties.

4 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996

6. The learned counsel for the appellants has submitted that the appellants who were relatives and servants of Her Highness Dharmakumari were unnecessarily arrested by the police due to enmity between Her Highness Dharmakumari and her brother in-law Khunnu Raja. Independent witnesses to the seizure were turned hostile. The prosecution story was doubtful, and therefore the appellants were acquitted from the charges of offence punishable under Sections 399 and 402 of IPC. The firearms which were manufactured by a company and having their number were the licensed firearms of Her Highness Dharmakumari which cannot be seized from the appellants. Shri S. Panveliwala has created a false case against the appellants, and therefore his testimony could not be believed. In support of his contention, learned counsel for the appellants has placed his reliance upon the judgments of the Single Bench of this Court in the case of "Vinod Kumar Shukla Vs. State of MP", [1999(2) MPLJ 374] and in the case of "Khilan Singh Vs. State of MP", [2010(4) MPHT 430]. Under such circumstances, it is prayed that the present appeal may be accepted.

7. On the other hand, learned counsel for the State has argued in support of the impugned judgment on the ground that conviction and sentence directed by the trial Court appears to be correct, hence no interference is warranted by this Court.

5 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996

8. After considering the submissions made by learned counsel for the parties and looking at the facts and circumstances of the case, it is to be considered as to whether the testimony of Shri S. Panveliwala can be discarded? Whether any prohibited weapon is seized from each of the appellants? And whether the sentence awarded to the appellants can be reduced?

9. The evidence on record has been carefully scrutinized by this Court. It is apparent that all the independent witnesses including Lachchhi (PW-5) were turned hostile, and therefore remaining witnesses like Vijay Raghav etc. were given up by the prosecution. Shri S. Panveliwala (PW-8) has stated about the entire incident and Head Constables Ramkishore (PW-1), Gaya Prasad (PW-2) and Sub Inspector Bati (PW-4) were also examined to corroborate the testimony of Shri S. Panveliwala. A police officer is required to attend so many investigations in a day, and therefore it is not possible for him to give the true story of a particular incident without perusal of such documents. Shri S. Panveliwala has given the evidence on the basis of various seizure memos on which his signature was present, but the Head Constables Ramkishore and Gaya Prasad along with Sub Inspector Bati had no opportunity to put their signatures on the various documents, and therefore their testimony should be examined according to the evidence given by them. Sub Inspector Bati shown his 6 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 ignorance as to how the independent witnesses were called by Shri S. Panveliwala. He admits that when they left the Police Station, the independent witnesses were not with them. They did not stay in the midway to collect the witnesses but the seizure was done before the witnesses. Looking at the testimony of Sub Inspector Bati, it appears that either he was not present at the time of seizure or seizure did not take place at the spot. Similarly, Head Constable Ramkishore has admitted that there was a single door in the room of appellant Narendra Singh which was covered by the police. However, he has admitted that out of eight culprits, two culprits were disappeared from the spot and six culprits could be arrested whereas Shri Pannawala had prepared the seizure memos Ex.P-4 to Ex.P-11 from the spot. If two culprits were disappeared, then how the seizure took place with these two culprits. Under such circumstances, it appears that either the Head Constable Ramkishore was not present at the time of raid or seizure did not take place at the spot. It was prepared thereafter. Under such circumstances, the testimony of the Head Constable Ramkishore and Sub Inspector Bati does not confirm the testimony of Shri S. Panveliwala but it contradicts the fact of the seizure. Similarly, the testimony of Gaya Prasad (PW-2) also appears to be incorrect. He has stated that there were three parts of police force prepared for the raid in the house of appellant Narendra Singh, 7 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 whereas Shri S. Panveliwala has stated that there was a single part of police force to raid in the house of appellant Narendra Singh. It appears that the Head Constable Gaya Prasad has stated the story in a routine manner as it should be given for the offence under Sections 399 and 402 of IPC. Under such circumstances, the testimony of Shri S. Panveliwala is not at all corroborated by the evidence given by the Head Constables Gaya Prasad, Ramkishore or Sub Inspector Bati.

10. The testimony of an Investigation Officer can be believed if it appears to be believable. In the case of "Modan Vs. State of Rajasthan", (AIR 1978 SC 1511) and in the case of "Tahir Vs. State of Delhi", (AIR 1996 SC 3079) it is held by the Hon'ble Apex Court that the testimony of police officials, merely because they belong to police force cannot be thrown away. It is not the rule of law or evidence that the conviction cannot be recorded on the evidence of police officials if they are found reliable or unless their testimony is corroborated by some independent evidence. The rule of prudence, however, only requires a more careful scrutiny of their evidence, because they could be said to be interested in the result of the case projected by them.

11. In the light of the aforesaid judgments of the Hon'ble Apex Court, if the scrutiny of a particular evidence given by Shri S. Panveliwala is considered, then it would be 8 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 apparent that from the various seizure memos, it is clear that some of the firearms shown to be seized were the firearms of Her Highness Dharmakumari. The Arms Clerk S.L.Verma (DW-3) has given the serial number of various weapons for which Her Highness was given a license though license was not renewed after December 1993. Under such circumstances, the defence taken by the appellants appears to be correct that such licensed guns were taken out from the safe of Her Highness Dharmakumari. Some letters written by Her Highness Dharmakumari were also shown in the defence. Those letters Ex.D-4, Ex.D-8 etc. were sent to higher authorities with a request that a bogus case was created by the police and police is not returning the weapons of Her Highness. Though the license was not renewed after December 1993, but it is not expected that licensed gun would have been given by Her Highness to her servants etc. Under such circumstances, it is highly doubtful that such weapons were seized from the appellants. If a doubt is created that some weapons were not seized from the appellants but they were taken from the safe of Her Highness, then it is possible that the remaining weapons could be planted by Shri S. Panveliwala.

12. SHO S. Panveliwala had adopted an erroneous procedure in dealing with the case. According to the letter Ex.P-15 sent by the Superintendent of Police Panna to the 9 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 FSL, it appears that all the seized materials were sent to the laboratory in a sealed condition, but it is nowhere mentioned in the seizure memos Ex.P-4 to P-11 that any of the weapons were sealed by Shri S. Panveliwala. Under such circumstances, it is nowhere clear that such weapons were sealed at the spot or at any other place. If they were sealed, then why the sample of the seal was not shown on the seizure memos. Under such circumstances, it could not be established that the weapons which were sent to the FSL, were seized from the appellants.

13. Similarly, after making entire seizure etc. Shri S. Panveliwala himself examined the witnesses Lachchhi and Vijay Raghav whereas he was the person who lodged the FIR, and therefore he was interested person and he should not have done the investigation in the case thereafter. Looking at the statements of Head Constables Ramkishore and Gaya Prasad along with Sub Inspector Bati, it appears that the story told by Shri S. Panveliwala appears to be incorrect. Two accused persons had disappeared from the spot, but firearms are shown to be seized from them. Similarly, the witnesses were not taken to the spot, because neither they were taken from the Police Station nor they were taken in the way, but the seizures memos are prepared with the signatures of these witnesses. Therefore, it appears that the witnesses were called to the Police Station and they were forced to put their signatures on the 10 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 various seizure memos. Under such circumstances, the testimony of Shri S. Panveliwala cannot be believed. Further more, if the fact is considered that some of the weapons were obtained from the safe of Her Highness Dharmakumari, then certainly the procedure adopted by Shri S. Panveliwala is not at all believable, and therefore his testimony cannot be believed. In the light of the judgments of the Single Bench of this Court in the case of Vinod Kumar Shukla (supra) and in the case of Khilan Singh (supra), the testimony of Shri S. Panveliwala may be disbelieved.

14. It is a strange case where the police has prepared a case against the appellant Lallu Kachhi whereas an air gun was seized from him for which no license is required. Therefore, the learned Additional Sessions Judge has rightly acquitted the appellant Lallu Kachhi from the charges of offence under Section 25(1)(a) of the Arms Act. Since the weapons were shown to be seized from the various appellants which were not in the possession of those appellants, but which were in the possession of Her Highness Dharmakumari whereas Her Hhighness Dharmakumari was not made an accused in the case. If the license of Her Highness was expired, a case was to be prepared against Her Highness Dharmakumari and not against her relatives and servants.

11 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996

15. The learned counsel for the appellants has also challenged the sanction given by the District Magistrate. The District Magistrate had given the sanction Ex.P-1 under the provisions of Section 39 of the Arms Act against the seven persons. The sanction is proved by Shri Ashraf Khan (PW-3), Clerk of the District Magistrate Office, Panna. He has stated that the entire diary was sent to the District Magistrate, who passed an order Ex.P-1. If the order Ex.P-1 is perused, then it would be apparent that the order is prepared by a typewriter in which the date of order, designation of the officer and other columns were kept blank. If the designation of the District Magistrate was not at all mentioned in the order, just below his signature, there is no reason as to why the designation was not typed on that order. If that order was passed by the District Magistrate by his own, then the date of order and other blank portions should not be left blank in that order. So many corrections are made in the order due to typographical error. Corrections are made in a different ink, whereas signature put by the District Magistrate is in a different ink. Though by perusal of the order, it can be said that the District Magistrate has used his judicial discretion in an appropriate manner. But it is surprising to know that he gave the sanction for prosecution against the appellant Thallu @ Dugpal who had a sword at the time of incident. There is no provision of giving any sanction for the 12 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 prosecution for a prohibited arm like a sword. Prosecution sanction can be given for the firearms only, and therefore it is apparent that the District Magistrate did not use his judicial discretion in an appropriate manner. On the contrary, it appears that he signed the order which was placed before him by the office, otherwise he could not have given sanction under Section 39 of the Arms Act against the appellant Thallu @ Dugpal, who had a sword in his possession. Under such circumstances, in absence of the valid sanction, the appellants could not be convicted for the offence punishable under Section 25(1)(a) of the Arms Act.

16. On the basis of the aforesaid discussion, it is apparent that the testimony of the police officials including Shri S. Panveliwala is not reliable at all. It is not proved beyond reasonable doubt that various prohibited arms were found in the possession of the appellants. Similarly, it is not proved that the District Magistrate had given a valid sanction for prosecution under Section 39 of the Arms Act, and therefore the appellants cannot be convicted for the offence under Section 25(1)(a) of the Arms Act. However, it is a settled law that if any doubt is created, then certainly the benefit of doubt is to be given to the appellants. Under such circumstances, the appeal filed by the appellants deserves to be allowed.

17. Consequently, the instant appeal filed by the appellants is allowed. The conviction as well as sentence 13 Criminal Appeal No.2061/1996 directed by the trial Court against the appellants for commission of offence punishable under Section 25(1)(a) of the Arms Act is hereby set aside. They are acquitted from the charges appended against them.

18. The legal representatives of Her Highness Dharmakumari may obtain those firearms back which were listed in her license and if license is renewed at present. Appellant Narendra Singh can get his air gun from the trial Court if he is able to show his ownership to that air gun. No interference is required in the order passed by the trial Court relating to remaining arms.

19. Presence of the appellants is no more required, hence it is directed that their bail bonds shall stand discharged.

20. A copy of this judgment be sent to the concerned trial Court with its record for information and compliance.

(N.K.Gupta) Judge 16/08/2012 Ansari
